docs.snippet: INTERNATIONALA3-22     In Blow to U.S., Russia

docs.lead_paragraph: As baby boomers and their parents grow older, more families must grapple with the medical, financial and legal questions that often accompany caregiving. As part of the Times Talks series of moderated discussions, experts on various aspects of eldercare shared insights into the best ways to meet these challenges. Below are excerpts of the discussion, which was moderated by New York Times reporter Jane Gross.

headline.main: Taking Care: Helping Loved Ones as They Age

docs.snippet: As baby boomers and their parents grow older, more families must grapple with the medical, financial and legal questions that often accompany caregiving. As part of the Times Talks series of moderated discussions, experts on various aspects of...

docs.lead_paragraph: John Edwards remains very much in contention in Iowa and in the race for the Democratic nomination, and over the weekend the Edwards camp unveiled a new TV ad titled, "Fight." In it, Mr. Edwards looks into the camera and declares war on inequality. "The moral test of our generation is whether we're going to allow this broken system to go on without a fight or take on corporate greed and stand up for the middle class and American jobs before it's too late," he says. "Saving the middle class is going to be an epic battle, and that's a fight I was born for."

headline.main: If You're Middle Class, Please Stand Up

docs.abstract: All the Democratic candidates, to one extent or another, have been blurring the distinction between the poor and the "middle class."
docs.snippet: All the Democratic candidates, to one extent or another, have been blurring the distinction between the poor and the "middle class."

headline.main: For Congress, the Clock is Ticking

docs.abstract: Congress still has a laundry list of things to accomplish. For Democrats, that includes proving they are capable and productive. For Republicans, it includes proving that the Democrats are not.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Disability Cases Last Far Longer as Backlog Rises'' (front page, Dec. 10):

headline.main: Disabled Need Help Now, Not Later

docs.abstract: Six letters respond to Dec 10 article about lengthening delays in resolution of Social Security disability claims; Martin Gittelman, past president of American Assn for Psychosocial Rehabilitation, Alfred Freedman, past president of American Psychiatric Assn, and Ted J Bliman score Bush administration for failure to help disabled; Michelle Lerner comments on financial difficulties incurred while waiting for hearings; Jeffrey Kassel, former employee of NY State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, says brain drain of analysts contributes to case backlog; Johnson Tyler, director of South Brooklyn Legal Services unit for Social Security and disability cases, blames quality assurance program for denying eligible claims; David Levner fears weakening of public support for Social Security; drawing
